Comment: English opening.  White generally responds Pe5 or Nf6.
Pe5.  White does well with Nc3 or maybe Pg3.
For some reason black seems to do better when white plays this, though it looks perfectly fine to me.
Black opts for a quick checkmate.  White should expect Bc5.  Not that this move must be defended against just yet.  But Nf3 should defend against that just fine.
...this move too works, though white's pawns may get doubled by BxBe3 (in a couple of moves).
Yes, black is eying QxPf2#.  White knows better than to fall for such cheap theatrics.
The knight!  Excellent.  This is rule 2:  Can I prevent force mate?  (In this case, checkmate equals force mate in one).

Mm, here the queen was already defending Nf3.  Black wants this knight because it is the only piece defending Bg5.  BxNf3, BnBf3, QxBg5 for free.  Always a shame to drop 3 points before the tenth move.

The bishop for pawn was not a good idea.  Black does not gain sufficient advantage pulling the white king into the field.  But black still has a free bishop after the bishop/knight trade.
Completely wrong.  This bishop was free.  And easy.
Completely wrong.  This bishop was free.  And easy.
:)  White will ignore the bishop threat in exchange for a rook.
Remarkable.  NxPc7+ nets white a cheap rook.
This is no longer a hollow threat given that the queen is covering white's h rook.
?  No.  Black can easily prevent the loss of Ra1 with BxNd5.
?  No.  Black can easily prevent the loss of Ra1 with BxNd5.
That wasn't it.  Although black saves a pawn, it still costs a rook.  Na6 would be the proper way to stop white's knight aggression.
Finally!  I thought this day would never come.
Tasty.  Even if white loses the knight, 5 points is more than 3 points.
Tasty.  Even if white loses the knight, 5 points is more than 3 points.
Here I'm thinking Qb3.  Black may respond with Pb6, and white does NxPb6 just to get something for the beast.
While white doubles black's pawns, the pawn trade would have been better.
Not so great.  Now this pawn is in the way.  Pd4 releases the fury of Be2 upon Pb5.  Plus, what prevents NxPb4?  It's like throwing the pawn's life away for naught.
